Author: .ayab
Content:
The Indonesian military by decades of neglect and willful ignorance by the officer class of the army has failed to maintain a force that is strong enough to defend the country against any peer adversary or even trying to face imminent and non-imminent players that could potentially harm Indonesia (i.e. China and co or USA). Even with the M.E.F (Minimum Essential Force), an effort by the government started under the SBY administration has failed time and time again to meet any goals that are laid out to be accomplished under 5 years for each phase.  One of the highlights of those failures has been the Korean and Indonesian joint partnership on building and licensing Korean-designed subs (which was also a license from West German design). The military has also failed to sufficiently stockpile ammunition and Pindad has not yet finished the batch of Ammunition (in varying calibers) that was ordered by Prabowo when he was still in the defense minister's office.

 one of my biggest fear is that we have the hardware after purchasing it from foreign supplier but not having enough ammo to sustain any operational tempo in any stretch amount of time. Yes, we could convert civilian factories to churn out ammunition and armor of any kind to feed the logistical need for any possible conflicts but I have doubts that we could translate even half of our industrial output to produce defense-related equipment, that is mainly because of the nature of our industrial output is not supported by readily available heavy equipment like CNC machine and etc.

Author: .ayab
Content: This post could be better titled: A Logistical and Production Capacity for the Indonesian Industrial Base, but due to the close relations between Indonesian weapon manufacturers and the military, i think its alright to broaden the topic for more leg room.

Author: the.og.green
Content: As an archipelagic country, we need more maritime patrol aircraft, submarine hunting aircraft, Airborne Early Warning and Control aircraft, and long range fighters to cover most of our airspace. More radar installations as a system redundancy in case other radar systems fails. The addition of AEW&C (Airborne Early Warning & Control) would also increase our capability to monitor our airspace. Fighters can also be guided by radar to intercept targets, GCI (Ground Controlled Interception). Not to mention the software and hardware updates for ease of maintenance and futureproofing our equipment.

Author: the.og.green
Content: If I was the defence ministry, I would focus more on air and naval power with the ground force being less of priority. How would you send ground forces out without the navy being involved?

Author: the.og.green
Content: I really like the message on our F-16, "proud of the past, ready for the future" I hope the higher ups really do deliver on this

Author: the.og.green
Content: Another point, since Indonesia is prone to natural disasters, adding more strategic and tactical airlift aircraft would increase both the amount and speed of aid delivery to those affected. The purchase of the newer Lockheed C-130J-30 is a step in the right direction.

Author: the.og.green
Content: Domestic industries also have potential in the military and civilian transport sectors. Just look at the CN235, I see potential in it. Unfortunately, not many countries' air forces are interested in buying it. If we want to further develop our domestic aircraft industry, we need capital and access to more advanced technology, perhaps one day we could develop a jet powered transport variant too.

Author: the.og.green
Content: Considering our geography, I think sticking with propeller-based aircraft might not be such a bad idea, since they tend to perform better at low speeds. This means they require shorter landing distances and are more capable of operating in remote areas with less developed airfields.
